question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The polynomial $p(x)$ satisfies $p(1) = 210$ and
\[(x + 10) p(2x) = 8(x - 4) p(x + 6)\]for all real numbers $x.$  Find $p(10).$
inference:
Let $x = 0$ to obtain
$$10p(0) = 8(-4)p(6)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(0) = -\frac{32}{10}p(6) = -3.2p(6)$$
Let $x = 1$ to obtain
$$11p(2) = 8(-3)p(7)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(2) = -\frac{24}{11}p(7)$$

Let $x = \frac12$ to obtain
$$10.5p(1) = 8\left(-\frac32\right)p\left(\frac72\right)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(1) = -3p\left(\frac72\right)$$

Since $p(1) = 210,$ we now have
$$210 = -3p\left(\frac72\right)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p\left(\frac72\right) = -70$$

Finally, letting $x = \frac14$ yields
$$10.25p\left(\frac12\right) = 8\left(-\frac14\right)p\left(\frac{11}{2}\right)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p\left(\frac12\right) = -\frac{2}{10.25}p\left(\frac{11}{2}\right)$$

Since $p(1) = 210,$ we thus obtain
$$210 = -3p\left(\frac72\right) = 3(-70)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p\left(\frac72\right) = -70$$

So, letting $x = -3$ yields
$$-20p(-6) = 8(7)p(3)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(-6) = -\frac{56}{20}p(3) = -2.8p(3)$$

Since $p(1) = 210,$ we have
$$210 = -3p\left(\frac72\right) = 3(-70)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p\left(\frac72\right) = -70$$

Letting $x = \frac12$ yields
$$10.5p(1) = 8\left(-\frac32\right)p\left(\frac72\right)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(1) = -3p\left(\frac72\right) = -3(-70) = 210$$

Finally, letting $x = 5$ gives
$$60p(10) = 8(1)p(16)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(10) = \frac{8}{60}p(16) = \frac{4}{30}p(16) = \frac2{15}p(16)$$

Since $p(1) = 210,$ we now have
$$210 = -3p\left(\frac72\right) = 3(-70)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p\left(\frac72\right) = -70$$

So
$$p(10) = \frac2{15}(-70) = -\frac{140}{15} = -9.\overline{3}$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{-9.\overline{3}}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Setting $x = 4,$ we get
\[14 p(8) = 0,\]so $p(x)$ has a factor of $x - 8.$

Setting $x = -10,$ we get
\[8(-14)p(-4) = 0,\]so $p(x)$ has a factor of $x + 4.$

Setting $x = -2,$ we get
\[8p(-4) = 8(-6)p(4).\]Since $p(-4) = 0,$ $p(4) = 0,$ which means $p(x)$ has a factor of $x - 4.$

Let
\[p(x) = (x - 8)(x - 4)(x + 4) q(x).\]Then
\[(x + 10)(2x - 8)(2x - 4)(2x + 4) q(2x) = 8(x - 4)(x - 2)(x + 2)(x + 10) q(x + 6).\]This simplifies to $q(2x) = q(x + 6).$

Let $q(x) = q_n x^n + q_{n - 1} x^{n - 1} + \dots + q_1 x + q_0.$  Then the leading coefficient in $q(2x)$ is $q_n 2^n,$ and the leading coefficient in $q(x + 6)$ is $q_n.$  Since $q(2x) = q(x + 6),$
\[q_n 2^n = q_n.\]Since $q_n \neq 0,$ $2^n = 1,$ so $n = 0.$  This means $q(x)$ is a constant polynomial.  Let $q(x) = c,$ so
\[p(x) = c(x - 8)(x - 4)(x + 4).\]Setting $x = 1,$ we get
\[c(1 - 8)(1 - 4)(1 + 4) = 210,\]so $c = 2.$  Therefore, $p(x) = 2(x - 8)(x - 4)(x + 4),$ so $p(10) = 2(10 - 8)(10 - 4)(10 + 4) = \boxed{336}.$

So, letting $x = -3$ yields

Since $p(1) = 210,$ we have

Letting $x = \frac12$ yields
$$10.5p(1) = 8\left(-\frac32\right)p\left(\frac72\right)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(1) = -3p\left(\frac72\right) = -3(-70) = 210$$

Finally, letting $x = 5$ gives
$$60p(10) = 8(1)p(16)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p(10) = \frac{8}{60}p(16) = \frac{4}{30}p(16) = \frac2{15}p(16)$$

Since $p(1) = 210,$ we now have
$$210 = -3p\left(\frac72\right) = 3(-70)  \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad p\left(\frac72\right) = -70$$

So
$$p(10) = \frac2{15}(-70) = -\frac{140}{15} = -9.\overline{3}$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{-9.\overline{3}}$. I hope it is correct.

ground_truth:
Setting $x = 4,$ we get
\[14 p(8) = 0,\]so $p(x)$ has a factor of $x - 8.$

Setting $x = -10,$ we get
\[8(-14)p(-4) = 0,\]so $p(x)$ has a factor of $x + 4.$

Setting $x = -2,$ we get
\[8p(-4) = 8(-6)p(4).\]Since $p(-4) = 0,$ $p(4) = 0,$ which means $p(x)$ has a factor of $x - 4.$

Let
\[p(x) = (x - 8)(x - 4)(x + 4) q(x).\]Then
\[(x + 10)(2x - 8)(2x - 4)(2x + 4) q(2x) = 8(x - 4)(x - 2)(x + 2)(x + 10) q(x + 6).\]This simplifies to $q(2x) = q(x + 6).$

Let $q(x) = q_n x^n + q_{n - 1} x^{n - 1} + \dots + q_1 x + q_0.$  Then the leading coefficient in $q(2x)$ is $q_n 2^n,$ and the leading coefficient in $q(x + 6)$ is $q_n.$  Since $q(2x) = q(x + 6),$
\[q_n 2^n = q_n.\]Since $q_n \neq 0,$ $2^n = 1,$ so $n = 0.$  This means $q(x)$ is a constant polynomial.  Let $q(x) = c,$ so
\[p(x) = c(x - 8)(x - 4)(x + 4).\]Setting $x = 1,$ we get
\[c(1 - 8)(1 - 4)(1 + 4) = 210,\]so $c = 2.$  Therefore, $p(x) = 2(x - 8)(x - 4)(x + 4),$ so $p(10) = 2(10 - 8)(10 - 4)(10 + 4) = \boxed{336}.$
